expectations:
- MUST be in Latin American Spanish (teaching English)
      - Should cover English grammar structures (tenses, articles, phrasal verbs, conditionals)
      - Should cover vocabulary themes and communication scenarios
      - Should interleave grammar and vocabulary/situation chapters

      
  - Chapters should follow CEFR progression from A1 (beginner) to C2 (mastery)
  - ALL chapters must be content-domain chapters: grammar structures, vocabulary themes, or communication scenarios
  - NO skill-based chapters (pronunciation, listening, reading, writing) — those skills are built into every lesson automatically
  - NO culture chapters (history, traditions, cuisine, music, festivals, customs)
  - NO career or professional chapters (business language, workplace communication)
  - NO proficiency exam preparation chapters (DELE, JLPT, DELF, HSK, etc.)
  - NO literature or media chapters (books, films, songs, poetry)
  - Should cover grammar structures (verb tenses, nouns, articles, etc.) and vocabulary themes (food, travel, health, etc.)
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Titles should be concise, no filler words
  - Descriptions should be concise, no fluff (avoid "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.)
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises

rankings.reasoning: Model A has 65 chapters with excellent CEFR progression from A1 to C2. The content interleaves grammar (be, present simple, comparatives, conditionals, modals, passive, etc.) with vocabulary/communication scenarios (food, health, technology, travel) very well. Descriptions are concise and in Latin American Spanish. Titles are clear and to the point. No skill-based, culture, career, or exam prep chapters. Covers advanced topics like inversion, cleft sentences, participial clauses, hedging, and figurative language appropriately. Very comprehensive coverage of English grammar structures including phrasal verbs, articles, collocations, and register variation. Minor issue: some chapters like 'Fluidez conversacional' could be seen as skill-focused, but the description focuses on turn-taking and fillers which are communication structures. Overall excellent adherence to requirements.

Model B has 116 chapters with very thorough coverage. Excellent CEFR progression and good interleaving of grammar and vocabulary. Descriptions are concise and in Latin American Spanish. Strong grammar coverage including all tenses, conditionals, modals, passive, reported speech, and advanced structures like inversion and cleft sentences. Good vocabulary themes covered. However, some chapters border on skill-based (e.g., 'Mensajes, correos y notas breves: tono y fórmulas' - though focused on formulas/vocabulary). Chapter 'Trámites y servicios cotidianos' could be seen as slightly professional/career-oriented. The extensive chapter count means some topics are split across multiple chapters which could be seen as either thorough or fragmented. Strong overall quality with comprehensive coverage.

Model C has 149 chapters - very extensive coverage. Good CEFR progression. Interleaves grammar and vocabulary well. In Latin American Spanish. However, several issues: 'Trabajos y Profesiones' (Ch 19) is borderline career/professional content. 'Vocabulario Académico' (Ch 123) and 'Presentaciones' (Ch 124) border on professional/academic prep. 'Correspondencia Escrita' (Ch 126) could be career-focused. 'Negociación' (Ch 125) is clearly professional/workplace communication which violates the no-career chapters rule. Some titles have filler like 'Más Phrasal Verbs', 'Más Collocations', 'Más Conectores'. Descriptions use 'learn' occasionally in implied form. Good grammar and vocabulary coverage overall but the professional/career violations are notable.

Model D has 67 chapters with good CEFR progression. Concise titles and descriptions in Latin American Spanish. Good interleaving of grammar and vocabulary. However, several issues: 'Small talk y conversación informal' (Ch 51) and 'Lenguaje académico y estilo editorial' (Ch 65) border on skill/professional content. The description for Ch 65 mentions 'académico y profesional' which is borderline career content. 'Errores comunes y corrección estratégica' (Ch 36) is somewhat meta/skill-focused. Good grammar coverage including tenses, modals, conditionals, passive, reported speech, and advanced structures. Vocabulary themes well covered. Overall solid but with some borderline chapters.

Model E has 85 chapters with reasonable CEFR progression. In Latin American Spanish with concise descriptions. However, several significant issues: 'Crimen y Justicia' (Ch 62) is a very narrow topic that seems out of place. 'Discurso Formal y Académico' (Ch 74) is borderline professional/academic content. 'Arcaísmos y Lenguaje Literario' (Ch 80) violates the no literature chapters rule. Grammar coverage is good including advanced structures. Some vocabulary themes well covered. The interleaving is adequate. The literature chapter and very specialized topics like crime/justice are problematic violations.

Model F has 60 chapters with good CEFR progression. Concise descriptions in Latin American Spanish. Good grammar coverage including all major tenses, conditionals, modals, passive, causatives, and advanced structures like inversion and cleft sentences. Vocabulary themes covered well (food, health, technology, environment). Good interleaving of grammar and vocabulary. 'Temas sociales y globales' (Ch 59) is somewhat broad and could border on current affairs/culture. Overall clean adherence to requirements with no major violations. Descriptions are appropriately concise. Coverage progresses well from basic to advanced C2 level topics like subjunctive and complex sentence structures.

Model G has 97 chapters with thorough CEFR progression. In Latin American Spanish. However, significant issues: 'Trabajo y Profesiones' (Ch 17) is clearly career/professional content. 'Lenguaje Profesional Especializado' (Ch 71) explicitly covers 'negocios, finanzas, derecho' which is professional/career content - a clear violation. 'Lenguaje Académico' (Ch 54) and 'Lenguaje Periodístico' (Ch 87) border on professional content. 'Referencias Intertextuales' (Ch 69) mentions 'alusiones literarias' which violates the no-literature rule. The grammar and vocabulary coverage is otherwise comprehensive. The explicit career/professional chapters are significant violations that impact the score.

Model H has 128 chapters. In Latin American Spanish with generally concise descriptions. Good CEFR progression overall. However, some issues: 'Trabajos' (Ch 56) is professional/career content. 'Ciencia' (Ch 114) is a very specialized topic. 'Arte y creatividad' (Ch 126) though it says 'sin análisis', vocabulary about art could be considered culture-adjacent. 'Finanzas personales' (Ch 127) - while 'personal' is specified, this is borderline. Some titles are very short and could be clearer. Grammar coverage is comprehensive. Vocabulary themes adequately covered. Some chapter titles are too terse (e.g., 'Salud', 'La casa', 'Trabajos'). The professional content violation with 'Trabajos' is notable.

This model followed all instructions exceptionally well. It adhered strictly to the negative constraints (no business, no literature, no skills chapters) while ensuring the skills were integrated into the descriptions (e.g., noting pronunciation is practiced within lessons). It specifically used Latin American vocabulary (e.g., "mesero"). The progression from A1 to C2 is detailed and logical, with excellent coverage of advanced pragmatic nuances (hedging, mitigation, irony) often missing in other outputs. The interleaving of grammar and vocabulary is well-balanced.

Model A provided a very strong curriculum with concise, punchy titles and descriptions. It followed the interleaving and progression rules well. It successfully avoided most prohibited topics, although the title "Negociación" (Chapter 65) skirts the "no business" rule (though the description frames it as conflict resolution). It is slightly less comprehensive in the C1/C2 nuance compared to Model B, but otherwise excellent.

Model F followed the negative constraints well, avoiding business and literature chapters. The progression is logical and the interleaving is present. However, the advanced chapters become somewhat generic (e.g., "Maestría de la expresión") compared to the specific functional pragmatics found in Model B. It is a safe, compliant output but lacks the depth of the top two.

This model generally followed the structure and progression requirements. However, it explicitly included a "Lenguaje Literario" chapter (Chapter 71), which violates the prohibition on literature chapters. It also included a "Discurso Formal y Académico" chapter which borders on the professional/career prohibition. Otherwise, the content quality is good.

Model C has a good general structure but significantly violates the "NO career or professional chapters" rule towards the end. It includes chapters on "Vocabulario Académico," "Presentaciones," "Negociación," and "Correspondencia Escrita" (emails), which are typical Business/Academic English topics explicitly forbidden by the prompt.

Model D failed the structural requirement to "interleave grammar and vocabulary." It presents a large block of grammar chapters (1-35) followed by a block of vocabulary chapters (36-53), rather than mixing them. It also included writing skill chapters (Correspondence) which violates the "NO skill-based chapters" rule.

This model was too granular (112 chapters), leading to redundancy. It explicitly violated the negative constraints with chapters like "Phrasal verbs avanzados de negocios generales" (Business language). The pacing is slow, separating concepts that could be grouped.

Model G misunderstood the target audience. While it follows the structure, the content shifts into theoretical linguistics (Ergative constructions, Deixis, Semantic Prosody, Epistemic Modalization) rather than language learning. It also included professional specialized language and literary references, violating negative constraints.

Cumple muy bien: español LATAM, progresión CEFR implícita de A1 a C2, alterna gramática/vocabulario/situaciones de forma consistente, cubre tenses, artículos, phrasal verbs y condicionales con buen desglose (incluye past/future perfect, pasiva con modales, reported speech avanzado, inversión/clefts, hedging). Títulos y descripciones son mayormente concisos y sin “fluff”. Evita casi por completo capítulos prohibidos (no cultura, no exámenes, no carrera). Único roce: algunos capítulos de “mensajes/correos” pueden parecer habilidad de escritura, pero están planteados como fórmulas lingüísticas/registro, no como destreza.

Muy sólido en cobertura gramatical y temas comunicativos; buena intercalación y progresión hasta C2 (inversión, clefts, participial clauses, causatives, modales perfectos, condicionales mixtos, artículos avanzados, colocaciones/idioms). Títulos/descripciones bastante directos. Debilidades: incluye “Puntuación y formato” (se acerca a capítulo de escritura/skill), y algunos capítulos son muy meta (p. ej., “Comprensión de rapidez y elipsis” suena a listening/skill). Aun así, la mayor parte es contenido lingüístico válido.

Cobertura gramatical amplia y correcta, e incluye vocabulario/escenarios. Pero la organización es menos CEFR: primero lista mucha gramática “en bloque” y luego agrega vocabulario, con duplicaciones (p. ej., familia aparece dos veces; viajes/transporte se repiten). También incluye capítulos claramente skill-based (“Correspondencia escrita…”, “Resumir y parafrasear”) y roza lo profesional/ académico (“Lenguaje académico y estilo editorial”), lo cual viola restricciones.

Intercalación razonable y buena cobertura de estructuras clave (tiempos, condicionales, pasiva, reported speech, phrasal verbs). Sin embargo, varias formulaciones son incorrectas o poco apropiadas para enseñar inglés (“conjugación del verbo ser/estar” para to be), y aparecen temas potencialmente fuera de alcance o tipo “debate”/temas sociopolíticos (“Temas sociales y globales”) que no son escenarios comunicativos concretos. Progresión CEFR algo irregular y capítulos finales vagos (“Maestría de la expresión”).

Buena cobertura y mucha granularidad (incluye condicionales, pasiva, estilo indirecto, phrasal verbs, modales perfectos, inversión, clefts, causativos, etc.). Pero viola restricciones con capítulos de carrera/profesional (“Trabajos y Profesiones”, “Presentaciones”, “Correspondencia Escrita”, “Negociación”, “Vocabulario Académico”) y varios son skill-based (“Resumen y Síntesis” se acerca a writing/skills). También hay algo de “fluff” en descriptores y la progresión se vuelve larga y poco curada.

A1–B2 bastante bien cubierto con capítulos simples y directos; incluye condicionales, pasiva, relativas, reported speech y phrasal verbs. Pero la progresión y la curación son irregulares (duplicados y saltos), y aparecen capítulos prohibidos o dudosos: “Entretenimiento” (media), “Trabajos”, “Finanzas personales”, además de “negociación/persuasión” que roza lo profesional. Calidad general aceptable pero menos consistente.

Cobertura de gramática central aceptable y varios temas de vocabulario, pero hay errores conceptuales (mezcla “ser/estar” con to be; “género en sustantivos” no aplica igual en inglés). Incluye capítulos claramente prohibidos: “Crimen y Justicia” (dominio especializado), “Discurso Formal y Académico” (académico/profesional) y “Arcaísmos y Lenguaje Literario” (literatura). Progresión CEFR y selección temática poco alineadas con las restricciones.

Empieza bien y cubre bastante gramática, pero viola de forma clara varias restricciones: “Trabajo y Profesiones” (carrera), “Lenguaje Profesional Especializado” (business/derecho/finanzas), “Lenguaje Periodístico”, “Referencias Intertextuales” (cultura/literatura), además de un enfoque muy lingüístico-académico (evidencialidad, macroestructura, pragmática teórica) que se aleja de capítulos de gramática/vocabulario/escenarios prácticos. Títulos/descripciones menos CEFR y demasiado “universitarios”.
